title: Loss of ZBTB20 impairs circadian output and leads to unimodal behavioral rhythms
abstract: Many animals display morning and evening bimodal activities in the day/night cycle. However, little is known regarding the potential components involved in the regulation of bimodal behavioral rhythms in mammals. Here, we identified that the zinc finger protein gene <italic>Zbtb20</italic> plays a crucial role in the regulation of bimodal activities in mice. Depletion of <italic>Zbtb20</italic> in nerve system resulted in the loss of early evening activity, but the increase of morning activity. We found that <italic>Zbtb20</italic>-deficient mice exhibited a pronounced decrease in the expression of <italic>Prokr2</italic> and resembled phenotypes of <italic>Prok2</italic> and <italic>Prokr2</italic>-knockout mice. Injection of adeno-associated virus-double-floxed <italic>Prokr2</italic> in suprachiasmatic nucleus could partly restore evening activity in <italic>Nestin-Cre; Zbtb20</italic><sup>fl/fl</sup> (NS-ZB20KO) mice. Furthermore, loss of <italic>Zbtb20</italic> in <italic>Foxg1</italic> loci, but intact in the suprachiasmatic nucleus, was not responsible for the unimodal activity of NS-ZB20KO mice. Our study provides evidence that ZBTB20-mediated PROKR2 signaling is critical for the evening behavioral rhythms.
